description:
Young Mary follows a mysterious cat into the nearby forest and discovers an old broomstick and a strange flower, a rare plant that blossoms once every seven years. Together, the flower and the broomstick whisk Mary above the clouds, and far away to Endor College – a school of magic run by headmistress Madam Mumblechook and the brilliant Doctor Dee. But there are terrible things happening at the school, and when Mary tells a lie, she must risk her life to try and set things right.

(Source: Altitude Film Entertainment)
synonyms: Mary y la Flor de la Bruja
Mary e a Flor da Feiticeira
Mary y la flor de la hechicera

node.description:
[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/1179422512028864512)

Currently he is a member of [Studio Ponoc](https://anilist.co/studio/6147/), having formerly been a part of [Studio Ghibli](https://anilist.co/studio/21/) for over 18 years from 1996 to 2015. While he was still at Ghibli, he made his directorial debut as a 37-year-old with [The Secret World of Arrietty](https://anilist.co/anime/7711/), and became the youngest director of a theatrical feature produced by the studio. [Tomomi Mochizuki](https://anilist.co/staff/101821/), a director of a 1993 TV special, [Ocean Waves](https://anilist.co/anime/743/), is the youngest director of a Ghibli film at 34.

In 2015, Yonebayashi left with producer [Yoshiaki Nishimura](https://anilist.co/staff/121954/) and established Studio Ponoc. His first film at the new studio was [Mary and the Witch's Flower](https://anilist.co/anime/97981/).

Nominated for the Academy Award for Best Animated Feature in 2015 for his second film, [When Marnie Was There](https://anilist.co/anime/20555/).
British novelist.
A Japanese composer.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/1179422512028864512)

Currently he is a member of [Studio Ponoc](https://anilist.co/studio/6147/), having formerly been a part of [Studio Ghibli](https://anilist.co/studio/21/) for over 18 years from 1996 to 2015. While he was still at Ghibli, he made his directorial debut as a 37-year-old with [The Secret World of Arrietty](https://anilist.co/anime/7711/), and became the youngest director of a theatrical feature produced by the studio. [Tomomi Mochizuki](https://anilist.co/staff/101821/), a director of a 1993 TV special, [Ocean Waves](https://anilist.co/anime/743/), is the youngest director of a Ghibli film at 34.

In 2015, Yonebayashi left with producer [Yoshiaki Nishimura](https://anilist.co/staff/121954/) and established Studio Ponoc. His first film at the new studio was [Mary and the Witch's Flower](https://anilist.co/anime/97981/).

Nominated for the Academy Award for Best Animated Feature in 2015 for his second film, [When Marnie Was There](https://anilist.co/anime/20555/).

[Website](http://sekainoowari.jp/) | [YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/@SEKAINOOWARIch)

Japanese pop band from Tokyo consisting of four members:
- Nakajin (Band Leader, Sound Producer, Guitarist)
- [Fukase](https://anilist.co/staff/313562) (Lead Vocalist, Concept Maker)
- Saori (Pianist, Stage Producer)
- DJ LOVE (DJ, Sound Choice, Comedic Talk)
Founded [Studio Ponoc](https://anilist.co/studio/6147/) together with several Ghibli employees in 2015.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/大塚伸治)

The epitome of the versatile animator capable of adapting to any anime to do outstanding work in that style. Ootsuka's animation is professional but always full of personality and a special verve. 

He is one of the pillars of [Studio Ghibli](https://anilist.co/studio/21/)'s animation. Not confined to the Ghibli style, he has always searched for new means of expression, having done everything from the photorealistic to the cartoonish. The wonderful feeling of weight in the movement of Toshio running around the train station in [Only Yesterday](https://anilist.co/anime/1029/), the delightful bodyguards in [The Cat Returns](https://anilist.co/anime/597/), the little robot coming out of the water in the final episode of [FLCL](https://anilist.co/anime/227/) - all of these are quintessential Ootsuka. 

None other than the animation director of [Tokyo Godfathers](https://anilist.co/anime/759/) has conceded that the film was originally conceived as a project to showcase Ootsuka's talents, in the same way [Genma Taisen](https://anilist.co/anime/1626/) was a vehicle for [Yoshinori Kanada](https://anilist.co/staff/106398/). Most of Ootsuka's scenes in the film were drawn entirely by himself, with no in-betweens, and his cuts which were the first finished, had a determining influence on the direction of the animation by the rest of the animators. 

(Source: [Pelleas](http://www.pelleas.net/animators/#20))

Hamasu's animation mainly focuses on character acting, and his scenes often feature minimal camerawork with a heavy emphasis on expressive facial and body animation. Much like [Kouichi Arai](https://anilist.co/staff/121208/), he was heavily influenced by [Junichi Hayama](https://anilist.co/staff/140660/) and the late '80s realism. Early in his career he was employed at Toei Animation, and was thus a recurring presence in the studio's OVA works such as [Xanadu](https://anilist.co/anime/5920/), [Crying Freeman](https://anilist.co/anime/1153/) and [Vampire Wars](https://anilist.co/anime/1765/). His rising prominence during the early '90s allowed him to participate on [Ghost in the Shell](https://anilist.co/anime/43/), and from thereon he has been in high demand for feature films.

In 1993, Hamasu animated the car chase on [Satoshi Kon](https://anilist.co/staff/99580/)’s episode of the [JoJo’s Bizarre Adventure](https://anilist.co/anime/666/). The scene impressed Kon enough for Hamasu to end up as a character designer and animation director on [Perfect Blue](https://anilist.co/anime/437/). He was also set to serve a similar role in [Millennium Actress](https://anilist.co/anime/1033/), but was replaced in the role by [Takeshi Honda](https://anilist.co/staff/103303/) due to having contracted a severe tendon inflammation. He appeared on all of Kon’s films, as well as [Paranoia Agent](https://anilist.co/anime/323/) until the director's passing.

More recently he has mostly worked on [Ghibli](https://anilist.co/studio/21/) and [Hosoda](https://anilist.co/staff/100067/)'s films.
Originating from [Studio Ghibli](https://anilist.co/studio/21/).
[Twitter](https://twitter.com/altamontagna170)
[Twitter](https://twitter.com/tokyo_mono)
[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/尾崎和孝)
Originating from [Studio Ghibli](https://anilist.co/studio/21/).

As a teenager Yamashita was influenced by the works of [Yoshiyuki Tomino](https://anilist.co/staff/97337/) and [Tomonori Kogawa](https://anilist.co/staff/105957/), and was inspired to become an animator.

After graduating from Kurashiki Minami High School, he moved to Tokyo to become an animator and joined Bevore. After Bevore's dissolution, he joined Atelier Giga, and from there he joined Project Team Muu. There he was jointly in charge of the character designs, animation direction and storyboards for [Giant Robo the Animation: The Day the Earth Stood Still](https://anilist.co/anime/2321/). The production took nearly 10 years, during which Yamashita gave it his all. After the production was over he started losing his motivation for animation. Though, it sparked again, after having met [Norio Matsumoto](https://anilist.co/staff/100991/) and [Tomohiro Hirata](https://anilist.co/staff/122071/) on the opening animation for a video game called, Gensou Suikogaiden. 

In 2001, Yamashita worked as a key animator on [Spirited Away](https://anilist.co/anime/199/), a [Studio Ghibli](https://anilist.co/studio/21/) feature film. There he was in charge of multiple scenes, most notably Chihiro and Haru's free fall at the end of the movie. This earned him high high praise from [Hayao Miyazaki](https://anilist.co/staff/96870/), and he was thus selected as one of the animation director's for [How's Moving Castle](https://anilist.co/anime/431/). Since then he has served as an animation director on most of Ghibli's movies.

In 2018, Yamashita directed "The Invisible Man," a short film part of the anthology collection [Modest Heroes](https://anilist.co/anime/103887/), produced by [Studio Ponoc](https://anilist.co/studio/6147/). The film won the Newcomer's Award in the Animation Division at the 22nd Japan Media Arts Festival

Married to [Miho Shimogasa](https://anilist.co/staff/116279/).

Originating from [Toei Animation](https://anilist.co/studio/18/) where he was employed at until the production of [Summer Wars](https://anilist.co/anime/5681/). He is an apprentice of [Takaaki Yamashita](https://anilist.co/staff/110187/)'s, whose style of animation has strongly influenced him.

Married to [Miyako Kitada](https://anilist.co/staff/167718/).

Freelance, formerly affiliated with [Sanrio](https://anilist.co/studio/150/). Nowadays she mostly works on feature films.

[Tetsuya Nishio](https://anilist.co/staff/103725/) deems her one of the most trustworthy animators.

A veteran animator particularly well-known for her work in [Studio Ghibli](https://anilist.co/studio/21/) films.

She began her career at [Shin-Ei](https://anilist.co/studio/247/) before joining the newly established [Telecom](https://anilist.co/studio/94/), where she ended up as one of the studio's leading animators on the [Lupin III](https://anilist.co/anime/1425/) series. Having ended up working with [Hayao Miyazaki](https://anilist.co/staff/96870/) on multiple occasions it was quite natural for her to find herself in Ghibli's films. She has worked as a key animator on every Miyazaki film except for [Nausicaa](https://anilist.co/anime/572/) and [Laputa](https://anilist.co/anime/513/).

She excels in everything related to action such as explosions, sword fights, car chases and crowd shots. [Yasuo Ootsuka](https://anilist.co/staff/136873/) said that Tanaka was "born to animate," and [Satoru Utsunomiya](https://anilist.co/staff/101489/) admits to being outshined by her work.

_Note: Not to be confused with either the [voice actress](https://anilist.co/staff/95100/) or the [production manager](https://anilist.co/staff/208269/) by the same name._
Originating from [Studio Ghibli](https://anilist.co/studio/21/Studio-Ghibli).
Originating from [Ajia-do](https://anilist.co/studio/30/).
Freelancer formerly affiliated with [Telecom Animation Film](https://anilist.co/studio/94/).

[Twitter](http://twitter.com/i/user/336690901)

Originating from [Doga Kobo](https://anilist.co/studio/95/).

[Twitter](https://x.com/DkruaPUOPy88675)

Originating from [J.C. Staff](https://anilist.co/studio/7/). Noted for his standout effects animation.
